column1: A defect in the GALC gene causes Krabbe disease.
Without it, myelin breaks down, brain cells die, and nerves in the brain and other body areas do not work properly.

Symptoms of early-onset Krabbe disease are: - Changing muscle tone from floppy to rigid - Hearing loss that leads to deafness - Failure to thrive - Feeding difficulties - Irritability and sensitivity to loud sounds - Severe seizures (may begin at a very early age) - Unexplained fevers - Vision loss that leads to blindness - Vomiting Symptoms of late-onset Krabbe disease: Vision problems may appear first, followed by walking difficulties and rigid muscles.
On average, infants with early-onset Krabbe disease die before age 2.
People who develop the disease at a later age have survived into adulthood with nervous system disease.
Call your health care provider if your child develops symptoms of this disorder.
